sections.section: Trello is a collaboration tool that organizes your projects into boards that show who is working on tasks and what progress is being made. This tutorial demonstrates how to develop and run a message flow that connects to Trello and retrieves boards. This tutorial requires access to Trello. The tutorial provides a partially completed message flow and detailed steps describing the development process step-by-step. A summary of what you will do is provided here:
1. Create a local integration server which has a vault for storing credentials
2. Launch the connector discovery process using a policy project which will be used to store a Trello policy containing connection information.
3. Select the object and action which the Trello Request node will execute
4. Save the results of the connector discovery process
6. Deploy and test the message flow, policy and credentials using the local integration server

For the convenience of more experienced users, the tutorial also provides a more complete version of the message flow, for which the connector discovery process has already been completed.  Instructions describe how to edit connection information in the policy, and how to create credentials to access your own instance of Trello.

overview.name: Create
overview.heading: Import projects
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

sections.section: When you click Import, three projects will be imported into your workspace:

ExampleTrello contains a single message flow named ExampleTrelloFlow. To save you time, most of the message flow is ready for use, but the Trello Request node has not yet been configured. This tutorial will guide you through the configuration of the node. The flow is driven by an HTTP input containing any well-formed JSON data, and uses a FlowOrder node to first acknowledge the input by echoing the same data back to the requesting client. Second in the flow sequence, the Trello Request node communicates with Trello. This node has its three output terminals (Failure, Out and NoData) wired to three separate Trace nodes to capture the results.

CompleteExampleTrello is very similar to ExampleTrello but the message flow which it contains, named CompleteExampleTrelloFlow (which exposes a different URL Fragment), has already had its Trello Request node configured, and an associated policy with connection information has already been generated. If you're already familiar with connector discovery, this application may be helpful to demonstrate some administration concepts such as reusing discovered artifacts, editting policies and updating credentials. If you want to use this message flow, there are instructions later for updating the connection details and credentials for your Trello instance.
CompletePolicyProjectTrello contains a single policy named Trello1 which is used by the application CompleteExampleTrello.

sections.section: Create an Integration Server with a credential vault

details.details: From the Integration Explorer view in the bottom left corner of the Toolkit, right-click the Integration Servers folder and select the option to Create a local integration server. We will leave most of the options with their default values. Type in a value (at least 8 characters long) for the Vault Key property. The instructions later in the tutorial will assume a value of password123. Untick the check box at the bottom of the dialog which is labelled Start Integration Server. Click Finish. The local Integration Server will be created using a project in your Toolkit's workspace as its work directory. We deliberately don't want to start up the server until later in the tutorial, because when the server process runs it will lock the vault from being used by other processes. Before running the server we want to use the Toolkit Connector Discovery process to populate the vault with the credentials needed for communication with Trello. If you are already familiar with the Connector Discovery process you can now skip over the rest of the instructions in this Prepare section and move straight to the tutorial's Run section, Option 2.

When you imported the tutorial projects in the previous section, ExampleTrelloFlow in application ExampleTrello will have been opened for you. First, check the properties of the three trace nodes in the messge flow, which are configured ready for deployment on a Windows system (their File path property is set to use the directory C:\temp). If you are running on a different operating system, or if the file directory is not convenient for you, then feel free to change it. Next, select the Trello Request node and view its Properties window at the base of the screen. At this stage you should see an error stating that an action must be specified. Every Trello Request node (in fact, every Discovery Connector node) requires configuration to define what action it should execute against what object in the endpoint system. You make these decisions using the Connector Discovery process. Click the Launch Connector Discovery button.

The Launch Connector Discovery wizard will open. The process of connecting to Trello and discovering information from it, will cause your Trello credentials to be saved in the vault, and your Trello connection information to be saved in a policy. Fill out the three required property values shown below and then click the Launch Discovery button:
Policy Project: Click the New button and create a policy project named ExamplePolicyProjectTrello

Work directory: Click the Browse button and navigate to the TEST_SERVER directory in your Toolkit workspace. For example, this would be C:\workspace\TEST_SERVER if your Toolkit workspace were at C:\workspace.
Vault Key: Type the same vault key which you used when creating your local integration server (named TEST_SERVER) earlier in the tutorial, for example password123

A new Configure connector node window will open. If you had previously connected to a Trello system then a list of those connections would be displayed, but in this example the status of the Trello connector is shown as Not connected. Before you use the Trello Request node in a message flow as part of this tutorial, you will need to have access to Trello. Underneath where the panel says Not connected, expand the section named Boards and choose the action Retrieve boards. The list of objects and actions will be replaced with a Connect button. Click the Connect button. Fill out the requested connection information for your Trello account including the Application key, and Access token. You may need to wait a few seconds for the connection to be made. A dropdown will appear asking you to select the Team for which the boards will be retrieved. Choose your team and for simplicity change the Maximum number of items to retrieve from its initial setting of 10 down to 1, and change the radio button to Process 1 item from the collection.

At the top of the window click the Save button, and you should see a confirmation message briefly appear. Close the Configure connector window and return to the Toolkit. It is important to remember this step otherwise the vault will remain locked and you will be unable to start your integration server TEST_SERVER when you come to test the flow in the last section of the tutorial. You will now find that the properties of the Trello Request node in the message flow have been updated. Save the message flow. Explore the properties of the Trello Request node. The Basic properties tab will now display a short description of Retrieve boards, along with the Action (RETRIEVEALL) and the Object (Board). On the Connection properties tab, the Policy will have been configured as {ExamplePolicyProjectTrello}:Trello1.

sections.section: Option 1: Use the Flow Exerciser to test the tutorial scenario

details.details: In the Integration Explorer view of the Toolkit, right-click TEST_SERVER and select the option to Start.
Once the server has started, drag and drop deploy the policy project ExamplePolicyProjectTrello in to TEST_SERVER.
Return to ExampleTrelloFlow.msgflow and click the Flow Exerciser icon to start testing the flow.

Click the Send Message icon . Create a new test message to invoke the HTTP Input node. Use an empty JSON input message like this: {}. Click Send and your message is sent to the HTTPInput node. You will receive an empty JSON message echoed back as a reply. You may also see a highlighted path through the flow. Sometimes there may be a short pause before the data is returned from Trello, so you may need to click the View Path icon in the Flow Exerciser toolbar in order to see the highlighted path carry on past the Trello Request node and into a Trace node at the end of the message flow. Click on the highlighted path coming out of the Trello Request node to see the data which has been retrieved.

sections.section: Option 2: Using the alternative provided application named CompleteExampleTrello to test the tutorial scenario

details.details:
In order to reuse the completed application which is provided with this tutorial, you must configure your integration server with credentials for communicating with your Trello instance. Launch a command console session, and run the following command to create these credentials:
mqsicredentials --work-dir <YourToolkitWorkspace>\TEST_SERVER --vault-key password123 --create --credential-type trello --credential-name CompletePolicyProjectTrello_Trello1 --client-id <YourTrelloAPIKey> --access-token <YourTrelloAccessToken>
Back in the Toolkit, in the Integration Explorer view, right-click TEST_SERVER and select the option to Start.
Drag and drop deploy the policy project CompletePolicyProjectTrello to TEST_SERVER.
Return to CompleteExampleTrelloFlow.msgflow and click the Flow Exerciser icon to start testing the flow.

Click the Send Message icon . Create a new test message to invoke the HTTP Input node. Use an empty JSON input message like this: {}. Click Send and your message is sent to the HTTPInput node. You will receive an empty JSON message echoed back as a reply. You may also see a highlighted path through the flow. Sometimes there may be a short pause before the data is returned from Trello, so you may need to click the View Path icon in the Flow Exerciser toolbar in order to see the highlighted path carry on past the Trello Request node and into a Trace node at the end of the message flow. Click on the highlighted path coming out of the Trello Request node to see the data which has been retrieved.
